title: AB 247
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 30652 of the Food and Agricultural Code is amended to specify the allocation of fees and fines collected for dog license tags. The funds are to be used for various purposes including issuance of tags, enforcement of related ordinances, compensation for livestock damages caused by dogs, emergency care for animals, and training for animal control officers. Section 830.9 of the Penal Code is also amended. Section 830.9 of the Penal Code is amended to allow animal control officers to exercise powers of arrest and serve warrants if they complete a training course. Officers appointed before July 1, 2016, must complete the training by July 1, 2017, unless their agency prohibits firearm use. Animal control officers appointed before January 1, 2016, with no break in employment longer than three years are deemed to have met training requirements. Those appointed after July 1, 2016, must complete a training course on powers of arrest and serving warrants within one year. Firearms training is not required for officers whose agency prohibits firearm use. Animal control officers appointed after July 1, 2016, must complete a training course on powers of arrest and serving warrants within one year of appointment. Directors, managers, and supervisors of animal control agencies must also complete this training. Animal control officers appointed after July 1, 2016, must complete a training course on powers of arrest and serving warrants within one year of appointment. Additionally, every animal control officer must complete 40 hours of continuing education every three years, sponsored by various accredited institutions and associations. Every animal control officer must comply with training requirements every three years, including coursework on powers of arrest, officer safety, animal-related laws, and conducting investigations. The California Animal Control Directors Association may determine the minimum hours and topics for continuing education. Animal control officers must complete training every three years, including coursework on various topics such as animal handling, care, diseases, and public health. Training records must be maintained by the officer's agency, and failure to complete the requirements within 90 days of expiration will result in suspension of authority. The section outlines that existing training requirements are not superseded, exempts peace officer animal control officers, and defines "firearms." It also addresses cost reimbursement to local agencies if mandated by the state.
